entries.title: William Blake: An Annotated Bibliography
entries.content: This bibliography serves as a comprehensive resource for scholars, students, and enthusiasts of William Blake. The following pages contain a carefully curated collection of bibliographic entries spanning Blake's works, critical responses, and scholarly analyses.
entries.chapter: INTRODUCTION

entries.title: How to Use This Bibliography
entries.content: The bibliography is organized into ten main parts, each focusing on a different aspect of Blake studies. You can navigate through these sections using the sidebar menu, or search for specific entries using the search function. Each entry provides bibliographic information and a brief description of the content.
entries.chapter: INTRODUCTION

entries.title: Blake Scholarship Organization
entries.content: This bibliography arranges Blake scholarship into clear categories for easy reference. From teaching resources and general introductions to specialized studies of Blake's specific works, the categories reflect the breadth of Blake scholarship available today.
entries.chapter: INTRODUCTION

entries.title: Digital Blake Resources Overview
entries.content: This section provides an overview of the digital resources available for Blake studies, including the William Blake Archive, digital editions, and other online repositories.
entries.chapter: INTRODUCTION

entries.title: Citation Guidelines for Blake Studies
entries.content: This guide outlines the recommended citation formats for Blake's works, including his illuminated books, manuscript writings, and letters. It also offers guidance on citing digital resources and archival materials.
entries.chapter: INTRODUCTION

entries.title: Blake Journals and Academic Publications
entries.content: An overview of the major academic journals dedicated to Blake studies, including Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly, Blake Studies, and other publications where Blake scholarship frequently appears.
entries.chapter: INTRODUCTION

entries.title: Teaching Blake: Digital Resources and Archives
entries.content: An overview of digital resources available for teaching Blake's works in undergraduate and graduate courses, with special emphasis on the William Blake Archive and other online repositories.
entries.chapter: PART I. TEACHING WILLIAM BLAKE

entries.title: Annotating Blake: A Guide for Student Research
entries.content: A practical guide for instructors teaching students how to annotate Blake's illuminated works, with strategies for addressing the interplay between text and image.
entries.chapter: PART I. TEACHING WILLIAM BLAKE

entries.title: Blake Journals: A Comparative Analysis
entries.content: An examination of the various academic journals dedicated to Blake studies, including their focus areas, submission guidelines, and impact in the field.
entries.chapter: PART I. TEACHING WILLIAM BLAKE

entries.title: Teaching Blake's Visual Art in the Classroom
entries.content: Strategies for incorporating Blake's visual art into classroom teaching, including techniques for visual analysis and interpretation.
entries.chapter: PART I. TEACHING WILLIAM BLAKE

entries.title: Blake's Poetry in Secondary Education
entries.content: Methods for introducing Blake's poetry to secondary school students, with lesson plans and discussion guides.
entries.chapter: PART I. TEACHING WILLIAM BLAKE

entries.title: Reading William Blake
entries.content: An overview of the issues confronting readers of Blake, with a survey of his works in illuminated printing.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: A Blake Dictionary: The Ideas and Symbols of William Blake
entries.content: Despite its age, remedied somewhat by Eaves's foreword, bibliography, and index, an indispensable reference for a basic understanding of Blake's obscure myth and symbolism.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: The Cambridge Companion to William Blake
entries.content: A very readable collection aimed at introducing new researchers to Blake. Some of its chapters were developed into content for the William Blake Archive.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: The Poetry of William Blake
entries.content: A well-received introduction to Blake's poetry aimed at an undergraduate audience, highlighting mostly the early illuminated books.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: A Guide to the Cosmology of William Blake
entries.content: A reference book on Blake's mythic system more recent than Damon's Blake Dictionary, which also includes useful information about Blake's circle and more contemporary bibliographical resources.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Glossary
entries.content: A concise list defining key words in Blake's mythology and symbolism. Adapted from Gourlay's 'A Glossary of Terms, Names, and Concepts in Blake,' published in Eaves's Cambridge Companion to William Blake.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake in Context
entries.content: A very useful collection of nearly forty short essays on Blake's relationship to various contexts and topics. Each chapter includes a list of further readings. A great starting point.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Mapping Blake's London
entries.content: The maps of Britain, the Holy Land, and London in the article, which were published in Blake's Poetry and Designs (1979, 2008), are very useful for visualizing Blake's syncretic fusion of biblical and British geography.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Reading William Blake
entries.content: A short, but compelling, analysis of some of the different dimensions at play in reading Blake.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake (1757-1827)
entries.publication: The Romantic Poets: A Guide to Criticism
entries.content: A survey of criticism with excerpts from three previously published books and an annotated list of further reading.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Urizen Now: Reading Anew William Blake's Response to his Times
entries.authors: Pinheiro de Sousa, Alcinda & Whittaker, Jason
entries.publication: Weaving Tales: Anglo-Iberian Encounters on Literatures in English
entries.content: On how to read Blake's works: 'Blake himself seems very strongly as an author to invite engaged and dialectical readings of his works' (13).
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake's Poetry: A Reader's Guide
entries.content: Aimed at advanced undergraduates. Includes an overview of Blake's context, expression, thought, and reception history, with study questions and a guide to further reading.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: A Guide to the Books of William Blake for Innocent and Experienced Readers
entries.content: An extensive overview of Blake's poetic works, with comprehensive annotations that synthesize important critical commentaries.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Palgrave Advances in William Blake Studies
entries.content: A collection of introductory essays that consider Blake from critical, historical, and cultural perspectives as might be presented in a critical theory course. Complements Eaves's Cambridge Companion well.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Visionary Physics: Blake's Response to Newton
entries.content: A very important study of how Blake incorporated the language of Newtonian science into his own symbolism.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Blake as an Artist
entries.content: A substantial introduction to Blake's work as an artist.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Blake's Apocalypse: A Study in Poetic Argument
entries.content: A one-time influential study of Blake's poetic career. The book's argument shaped Bloom's commentary to David V. Erdman's The Complete Poetry and Prose of William (1965, 1982, 1988).
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: The Art of William Blake
entries.content: Although dated in its understanding of Blake's artistic techniques and technologies, a still useful study of Blake as an artist and his relationship to the world of eighteenth-century art.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake and the Age of Revolution
entries.content: First published as William Blake, 1757-1827: A Man without a Mask in 1943. Along with David V. Erdman's Blake: Prophet Against Empire, an early and important examination of Blake within his historical and political context.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake and the Daughters of Albion
entries.content: An important feminist critique of both Blake and Blake criticism, focused primarily on the early illuminated books. Bruder's work continued in her collection, Women Reading Blake (2007), and a series of collected essays.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake, His Philosophy and Symbols
entries.publication: Boston and New York: Houghton Mifflin Company
entries.content: William Blake, His Philosophy and Symbols is the first thoroughly scholarly book about Blake, and as such it is of great importance. It is particularly valuable for the parallels it draws between Blake's works and an immense variety of recondite mythologies.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: The Theology of William Blake
entries.content: Davies attempts to assert Blake's religious orthodoxy, but he is illuminating on Blake's relations with the Swedenborgians, particularly in demonstrating the impossibility of the legend that Blake's father and family belonged to the New Church.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Words of Eternity: Blake and the Poetics of the Sublime
entries.content: An important study of how Blake's poetics invoked the sublime, both in terms of content and materially. De Luca coins the phrase, "wall of words," to describe pages of the illuminated books full of text.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: The Counter-Arts Conspiracy: Art and Industry in the Age of Blake
entries.content: An illuminating study that positions Blake within several artistic traditions and controversies, including the development of the English School of Art between the seventeenth and nineteenth centuries and the aesthetic issues created by new technologies of mechanical reproduction.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake's Theory of Art
entries.content: An influential articulation of Blake's theory of art in relationship to Neoclassicism and Romanticism, with a consideration of Blake's notion of audience.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Blake: Prophet Against Empire
entries.content: A key study that examines Blake within his historical context. Erdman's approach was so influential that historicist readings of Blake are sometimes categorized as "The School of Erdman."
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake and the Language of Adam
entries.content: A study of Blake's conception of language with an analysis of the paintings, Adam Naming the Beasts and Eve Naming the Birds, and most of the poetry. Includes a discussion of the Kabbalah and Hebrew, Blake's notion of the linguistic sign, his notion of the Fall, and Blake and other Romantic-era writers on language.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake Printmaker
entries.content: A very important study of Blake's career as a printmaker, which traces his training and his work in various forms of printing (intaglio, relief, etc.).
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: The Social Vision of William Blake
entries.content: Focusing on the illuminated books, an examination of Blake's thought about the individual and society, influenced by Marxism (the first two chapters are concerned with ideology), but the study also engages deeply with Christian and especially antinomian thought. Ferber builds to Blake's notion of "apocatastasis, or the restoration of all things" (xi).
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Fearful Symmetry: A Study of William Blake
entries.content: A profoundly influential study, which dominated twentieth-century Blake scholarship. Frye considered Blake primarily as a poet and artist (rather than a mystic), and his work led to Blake's canonization as a Romantic poet as well as shaping Frye's own Archetypal Criticism.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: William Blake, Poet and Painter: An Introduction to the Illuminated Verse
entries.content: A classic study of the poetry and the designs of the illuminated books. See Hagstrum's defense of associating Blake with the Sister-Arts Tradition in his "Blake and the Sister-Arts Tradition."
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Literal Imagination: Blake's Vision of Words
entries.content: A major study of how Blake used and envisioned words, with many ingenious readings of Blake's word play.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Blake Studies: Essays on his Life and Work
entries.content: A collection of some of Keynes's most important essays on Blake, all of which were published elsewhere but which were revised for both editions of the collection. The first edition (1949) had 17 essays, and the second edition (1971) had 29.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Dangerous Enthusiasm: William Blake and the Culture of Radicalism in the 1790s
entries.content: Focused on Blake's early illuminated books, a key study of Blake's relationship to religious enthusiasts of the era who shared his suspicion of Enlightenment-grounded radicalism. The study recasts Blake's relationship to millenarianism and to the polite circle of Joseph Johnson.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Blake's Composite Art
entries.content: A key study on the interplay of the visual and verbal in Blake's works. The phrase, "composite art," while popularized by Mitchell, was coined by Jean Hagstrum.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Vision and Verse in William Blake
entries.publication: Madison and Milwaukee: University of Wisconsin Press
entries.content: "A sensitive and responsible commentary on Blake's prosody" (BB #2335). Remains the best study of Blake's versification.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: Energy and the Imagination: A Study in the Development of Blake's Thought
entries.content: A pioneering study of Blake's intellectual development that examines the complexities of his relationship to the ideas of his time.
entries.chapter: PART II. GENERAL INTRODUCTIONS, HANDBOOKS, GLOSSARIES, AND CLASSIC STUDIES

entries.title: The Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake
entries.content: The standard scholarly edition of Blake's complete written works, featuring authoritative text and extensive annotations.
entries.chapter: PART III. EDITIONS OF BLAKE'S WRITING

entries.title: William Blake: The Complete Illuminated Books
entries.content: A collection of high-quality reproductions of Blake's illuminated books, accompanied by scholarly commentary and context.
entries.chapter: PART III. EDITIONS OF BLAKE'S WRITING

entries.title: Blake's 'Songs of Innocence and of Experience': A Critical Edition
entries.content: A scholarly edition of Blake's most accessible work, with detailed commentary and high-quality reproductions.
entries.chapter: PART III. EDITIONS OF BLAKE'S WRITING

entries.title: The William Blake Archive
entries.authors: Eaves, Morris; Essick, Robert N.; Viscomi, Joseph (eds.)
entries.content: A comprehensive online repository of Blake's visual and literary works, featuring high-resolution digital reproductions and scholarly apparatus.
entries.chapter: PART III. EDITIONS OF BLAKE'S WRITING

entries.title: William Blake: The Critical Heritage
entries.content: Comprehensive collection of contemporary responses to Blake's work from 1757 to 1863, including reviews, letters, and biographical accounts.
entries.chapter: PART IV. BIOGRAPHIES

entries.title: Blake Books
entries.content: Detailed bibliographical descriptions of Blake's writings with information about their production, printing, and contemporary reception.
entries.chapter: PART V. BIBLIOGRAPHIES

entries.title: Blake Books Supplement
entries.content: Supplementary volume to Blake Books with new information and corrections to the original bibliography.
entries.chapter: PART V. BIBLIOGRAPHIES

entries.title: The Life of William Blake
entries.content: The first full-length biography of Blake, which helped revive interest in his work. Includes accounts from Blake's friends and contemporaries.
entries.chapter: PART IV. BIOGRAPHIES

entries.title: William Blake: His Life and Work
entries.content: A biographical study that places Blake's work in the context of the revolutionary politics of his time.
entries.chapter: PART IV. BIOGRAPHIES

entries.title: Blake and Tradition
entries.content: A two-volume study of Blake's relationship to esoteric traditions and mystical thought, influencing interpretations of his symbolic language.
entries.chapter: PART VII. STUDIES OF BLAKE ARRANGED BY SUBJECT

entries.title: Blake, Politics, and History
entries.content: An examination of Blake's political thought in relation to the radical movements of his time, with emphasis on his response to the French Revolution.
entries.chapter: PART VII. STUDIES OF BLAKE ARRANGED BY SUBJECT

entries.title: Catalogue of William Blake's Drawings and Paintings in the Huntington Library
entries.content: A detailed catalogue of the Blake collection at the Huntington Library, with high-quality reproductions and scholarly descriptions of each item.
entries.chapter: PART VI. CATALOGUES

entries.title: William Blake's Commercial Book Illustrations
entries.content: A catalogue raisonn√© of Blake's work as a commercial illustrator, documenting his contributions to books by other authors.
entries.chapter: PART VI. CATALOGUES

entries.title: Digital Blake Collections Worldwide
entries.content: A catalogue of digital collections of Blake's works around the world, with descriptions of their holdings and access information.
entries.chapter: PART VI. CATALOGUES

entries.title: Blake and the Bible
entries.content: A study of Blake's engagement with biblical texts and traditions, exploring how he reinterpreted religious imagery in his art and poetry.
entries.chapter: PART VII. STUDIES OF BLAKE ARRANGED BY SUBJECT

entries.title: Blake and Revolution
entries.content: An analysis of Blake's political thought and its relationship to the revolutionary movements of his time, with emphasis on his radical vision of social transformation.
entries.chapter: PART VII. STUDIES OF BLAKE ARRANGED BY SUBJECT

entries.title: Blake's Visual Poetics
entries.content: A study of Blake's integration of text and image, introducing the concept of 'composite art' that has been influential in Blake scholarship.
entries.chapter: PART VII. STUDIES OF BLAKE ARRANGED BY SUBJECT

entries.title: Blake and Romanticism
entries.content: An examination of Blake's place in the Romantic movement, with emphasis on his influence on later poets and his uniqueness among his contemporaries.
entries.chapter: PART VII. STUDIES OF BLAKE ARRANGED BY SUBJECT

entries.title: William Blake's Songs of Innocence and of Experience: A Critical Edition
entries.content: A scholarly edition of Blake's most accessible work, featuring detailed commentary on each poem and plate.
entries.chapter: PART VIII. SPECIFIC WORKS BY BLAKE
entries.subheading: Songs of Innocence and of Experience

entries.title: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell: A Critical Study
entries.content: An in-depth analysis of Blake's provocative prose work, examining its philosophical ideas, artistic techniques, and cultural contexts.
entries.chapter: PART VIII. SPECIFIC WORKS BY BLAKE
entries.subheading: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell

entries.title: Jerusalem: Blake's Prophetic Vision
entries.content: A comprehensive study of Blake's longest and most complex prophetic book, exploring its themes, structure, and historical context.
entries.chapter: PART VIII. SPECIFIC WORKS BY BLAKE

entries.title: The Four Zoas: A Study of Blake's Epic
entries.content: An analysis of Blake's unfinished manuscript epic, examining its narrative structure, symbolic system, and relation to his other prophetic works.
entries.chapter: PART VIII. SPECIFIC WORKS BY BLAKE

entries.title: William Blake: Essays for S. Foster Damon
entries.content: A collection of scholarly essays on various aspects of Blake's work, published in honor of pioneering Blake scholar S. Foster Damon.
entries.chapter: PART IX. COLLECTIONS OF ESSAYS ON BLAKE PUBLISHED

entries.title: Blake, Modernity and Popular Culture
entries.content: An interdisciplinary collection exploring Blake's influence on modern literature, art, music, and popular culture.
entries.chapter: PART IX. COLLECTIONS OF ESSAYS ON BLAKE PUBLISHED

entries.title: Queer Blake
entries.content: A collection of essays examining Blake's work through the lens of queer theory, exploring gender, sexuality, and non-normative identities in his writings and art.
entries.chapter: PART IX. COLLECTIONS OF ESSAYS ON BLAKE PUBLISHED

entries.title: William Blake's Circle: A Biographical Dictionary
entries.content: A reference work providing biographical information on Blake's contemporaries, patrons, and associates.
entries.chapter: PART X. APPENDICES

entries.title: Blake in the Marketplace, 1990-2014
entries.content: A chronicle of sales, exhibitions, and other market activities involving Blake's works, with analysis of trends in collecting and valuation.
entries.chapter: PART X. APPENDICES

entries.title: Teaching Blake: Resources for Educators
entries.content: A compilation of teaching materials, lesson plans, and classroom resources for teaching Blake at various educational levels.
entries.chapter: PART X. APPENDICES

PART VIII. SPECIFIC WORKS BY BLAKE: Songs of Innocence and of Experience
The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
